items.title: Eligibility Criteria
items.content: IOTricity Season 2.0 is open to all undergraduate students of Academy of Technology (i.e. 1st to 4th Year Students). Mixed teams from different departments and years are allowed and encouraged.

items.title: Team Formation
items.content: Teams must consist of 3-5 members. Each team can have members from different academic years and departments. At least one team member should have basic knowledge of IoT concepts, microcontrollers, or embedded systems. Team composition cannot be changed after the registration deadline.

items.title: Registration Process
items.content: Registration will happen both offline and online. Teams must register through the official IOTricity website with complete details of all team members. Each participant can only be part of one team. Registration deadline is strictly enforced and no late registrations will be accepted.

items.title: Code of Conduct
items.content: All participants must maintain professional behavior throughout the event. Respectful communication, collaborative spirit, and ethical practices are mandatory. Any form of harassment, discrimination, or misconduct will result in immediate disqualification. Participants should follow all venue guidelines and safety protocols.

items.title: Problem Statement Selection
items.content: Teams will be assigned to houses (Yellow, Green, Blue, Red) based on their academic year and discipline. Each house has 10 unique problem statements. Teams must choose one problem statement from their assigned house and cannot switch between houses or problem statements after selection.

items.title: Development Phase
items.content: The online hackathon duration is 48 hours, and for the finals the duration is 5 hours. Teams must develop their IoT solution from scratch during the event. Pre-written code is not allowed, but teams can use open-source libraries and frameworks.

items.title: Hardware and Software Requirements
items.content: Basic hardware components (Arduino, Raspberry Pi, sensors) will be provided by the organizers during offline finals. But do note no components will be provided during the online hackathon. Teams can bring additional components but must declare them during registration. All software development should use commonly available platforms and tools. Cloud services and APIs are allowed for enhanced functionality.

items.title: Mentorship and Support
items.content: Industry mentors and technical experts will be available throughout the event for guidance. Teams can approach mentors for technical advice, troubleshooting, and project direction. However, mentors cannot write code or directly contribute to the solution. Technical support will be available for hardware issues and setup problems.

items.title: Project Deliverables
items.content: Teams must submit a working prototype demonstrating their IoT solution. A comprehensive project presentation (5-10 pages) documenting the approach, technical implementation, and results is required. All source code must be uploaded to a public GitHub repository with proper documentation and setup instructions. A video must be uploaded to YouTube explain the project with a demo.

items.title: Presentation Guidelines
items.content: Presentations should cover problem understanding, solution approach, technical implementation, demonstration, and future scope. Teams must prepare slides and ensure their prototype is ready for demonstration.

items.title: Submission Deadline
items.content: All submissions must be completed before the designated deadline. Late submissions will not be accepted under any circumstances. Teams should ensure their GitHub repositories are public and accessible. Presentation materials should be submitted in PDF format through the official submission portal.

items.title: Intellectual Property
items.content: Teams retain ownership of their developed solutions and code. However, by participating, teams grant IOTricity organizers the right to showcase and promote their projects. Open-source components used must be properly attributed. Commercial use of developed solutions is allowed after the competition.

items.title: Technical Implementation (20%)
items.content: Evaluation of the technical complexity, code quality, and proper use of IoT components. Judges will assess the integration of sensors, actuators, communication protocols, and cloud services. Bonus points for innovative use of emerging technologies like AI/ML, blockchain, or edge computing in the IoT solution.

items.title: Innovation and Creativity (25%)
items.content: Assessment of the uniqueness and creative approach to solving the problem statement. Judges will look for novel applications of IoT technology, creative user interfaces, and innovative features that set the solution apart from conventional approaches.

items.title: Problem Solving Approach (30%)
items.content: Evaluation of how well the team understood and addressed the problem statement. Judges will assess the logical approach, feasibility of the solution, and effectiveness in solving real-world challenges. Comprehensive problem analysis and solution design will be rewarded.

items.title: Presentation and Communication (15%)
items.content: Assessment of the team's ability to effectively communicate their solution, technical concepts, and project outcomes. Clear presentation skills, proper demonstration, and ability to answer technical questions will be evaluated. Professional presentation materials and delivery style are important.

items.title: Scalability and Impact (10%)
items.content: Evaluation of the potential for real-world deployment, commercial viability, and social impact. Judges will consider the solution's scalability, sustainability, cost-effectiveness, and potential to create positive change in society or industry.

items.title: Disqualification Criteria
items.content: Plagiarism or use of pre-existing solutions will result in immediate disqualification. Violation of code of conduct, harassment, or unprofessional behavior. Failure to submit required deliverables by the deadline. Use of prohibited resources or external assistance beyond allowed mentorship.

items.title: Health and Safety
items.content: All participants must follow safety guidelines and protocols. Proper handling of electronic components and equipment is mandatory. Participants should report any health issues or emergencies immediately. First aid and medical assistance will be available throughout the event.

items.title: Technical Support
items.content: Technical helpdesk will be available for hardware issues, software installation, and connectivity problems. Wi-Fi and power outlets will be provided at all workstations. Backup hardware components available in case of equipment failure. Technical documentation and tutorial resources accessible online.

items.title: Event Modifications
items.content: Organizers reserve the right to modify rules, timelines, or event format if necessary due to unforeseen circumstances. All participants will be notified immediately of any changes. In case of technical difficulties or emergencies, the organizers' decision will be final. Refund or rescheduling policies will be communicated if applicable.
